intro: Sisymbrium hispidulum var. herrerae, commonly known as the Herrera's hoary vetch, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, four-petaled flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is known for its hairy stems and leaves. It produces yellow or white flowers and has a taproot system that allows it to survive in arid conditions. This variety is often found in disturbed soils and is adapted to thrive in low-nutrient environments.
